conclusion: Car traveling at 30 m/s spots a truck moving at 10 m/s, 30 meters ahead.
Graph shows velocity vs. time for car and truck, labeled as a and b.
Vertical axis is velocity in m/s, horizontal axis is time in seconds.
Point 'a' on car's velocity curve, 'b' on truck's velocity curve.
Truck moves at constant speed of 10 m/s, car's speed decreases over time.
Car's velocity decreases from 30 m/s to 20 m/s in first second, then to 10 m/s at 5 seconds.
Determine if car catches up to truck before car's speed drops to truck's speed.
Car is initially 30 meters behind the truck.
Find equations for positions of car and truck as a function of time.
Truck's position equation: \( s_t = s_{t0} + v_t \cdot t \), with \( v_t = 10 \) m/s.
Car's velocity decreases from 30 m/s to 20 m/s in first second, then linearly to 10 m/s at 5 seconds.
Integrate car's velocity function over time to find position.
Approximate car's velocity function: quadratic from t=0 to t=1, linear from t=1 to t=5.
From t=0 to t=1: \( v_c(t) = a t^2 + b t + 30 \), with \( a + b = -10 \).
At t=1, velocity matches linear part: \( a + b = -10 \).
